paragraphs: is a
and
diverse country  with
and a population known for its multilingualism.
Mixing languages in everyday conversations, social media interactions, and musical compositions is a common practice.
The list provided below outlines frequently used terms and phrases used in South Africa. This compilation also includes borrowed
from neighboring countries such as
(formerly Swaziland),
, and
. Additionally, it may encompass linguistic elements from
nations like
and
based on the
South Africa is a country formed from centuries of immigrants, settlers, and colonisers. It has a long history of using racial slurs or derogatory phrases when speaking of the
. Some such words have more recently been reclaimed as a mark of pride and defiance (for example,
"Voetsek", or simply "tsek", is a fun way of telling someone to "fuck off". This is also used to scare unwanted animals away.
" or "

" is a derogatory phrase that literally translates to "Your Mom's hole" or "Your Mom's vagina". The term originates from Cape Western where it is most closely associated with the slang used by the Coloured community. This is often seen as more aggressive than the aforementioned phrase "voetsek".
Although still seen as offensive, over time it has become a less aggressive adjective used as an exclamation. Such as "it is
cold" when describing a surprisingly cold temperature.
Normally, in other English-speaking countries, when you say you're doing something "now", you would assume it means that you will do said thing right away

. In South Africa, the phrases "now now", "just now", and "right now" all have differing connotations: "Now now" often means minutes later; "just now" means hours later; and "right now" actually means now.
For example, the following line using South African slang:
"I am going to see a movie just now. I will drive there now now. I am at the movies right now."
...actually has the following meaning in standard usage:
"I am going to see a movie in an hour or so. I will (start to) drive there in a few minutes. I am at the movies now."
South Africa uses
spelling and punctuation, although some American spellings are common.
The following lists slang borrowings from the
(which include
and
). They typically occur in use in the South Africa
, but some have become increasingly popular among white youth. Unless otherwise noted these words do not occur in formal
The following slang words used in South African originated in other parts of the
and subsequently came to South Africa.
The majority of
in South Africa speak Afrikaans. Those who speak English use the equivalent English words as slang.

sy naam is Kom Terug en sy van is Bloedbek/Bloedneus
van die os op die wa af
veë jou gat aan dit af
waar val jy uit die bus uit/van die bus af?
word wakker, die dag word al swakker!

Jinne man, just put on your tekkies and your costume, don't be dof! We're going to walk to the beach and then go for a swim, if you want to come with you better hurry up, chyna. Ag nee, I stepped on a shongololo, I just bought new tekkies the other day! You know what, lets just forget about the beach and have a braai instead, all we need is some meat, mieliepap, some cooldrinks, maybe a brinjal and some other veggies. And if someone can bring some biscuits for a banofi pie, that would be great. Hey bru, it's a lekker day for a jol today, ek sê! I'm warning you my dad won't tolerate any gesuipery, he'll klap you stukkend! Is it? Ja, he's kwaai! He was tuning me just now from his bakkie my bokkie is a soutie and a rooinek. Eish! Well at least he's duidelik.
A Dictionary of South African English
A Dictionary of South African English
Writing South Africa: literature, apartheid, and democracy 1970–1995
Community and Conscience: The Jews in Apartheid South Africa
The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language

because of the team colours. A very popular local beer because of its high alcohol content.

, it is a title given to
, derived from the Aramaic word for
– to carry someone (normally a child) on one's back.
africtionary – Website for African Slang dictionary.
– oh man;
as the Afrikaans equivalent to "oh" (pronounced \jach\ like German ACHtung), "man" pronounced as in "mun" in "munches".
– both an expression of pity and sorrow, depending on context: Ag shame, daardie baba is te oulik! (Aw, that baby is so cute!); Ag shame, die arme hond is dood. (Ah shame, the poor dog died.)
– an older female authority figure. Derived from the English "aunt", with the original meaning still intact.
– breasts/boobs or plural of the word "aunt"

(pronounced \AAAH-WHE\) – said in excitement, as in: 'Aweh; my boss said I can go home early today.', 'or 'Ok, cool'.' Same as the English pop culture slang 'yas'. The word has many meanings or uses: "hello", "goodbye", "yes", "cool". Also associated with prison use. (Greeting) "Aweh, my bru." (Hello my friend). Similar:
– someone who talks a lot
– hangover (of Xhosa origin)
– cool; expression of appreciation for something very well accomplished
- lit "bowl ears", refers specifically to people who have
, like a bowl's handles.
– a utility truck or pick-up truck, now a mainstream word in South African English. Can also refer to a small plastic container/bowl.
– lit. "balls". Refers to the
or
- close male friend. Sometimes used to refer to an older man. Can also be used to describe an old man as irritable or crabby.
- father. "My 'ouballie' always used to tell us this story."
– lit. "ball-sack". Refers specifically to the
– lit. "scaredy-pants"
– really good, exciting, cool; as in "The rock-show was
." (Do not confuse with
.). Also means to be extremely angry(kwaad); as in "Ek is nou so
". Can also mean "crazy" in a very strong sense, as in "Are you befok?" – derogatory. Can also mean "to have sex with".
– lit. "extremely angry" similar to "diedonnerend", etc. Usually used to refer to a person who is often in a very bad mood.
– from Afrikaans
, which translates to "mountain", originally referring to vagrants who sheltered in the forests of
; now a mainstream word for a particular subculture of vagrants, or homeless persons, especially in Cape Town.
– lit. "better to be a scared Jan rather than a dead Jan". English equivalent is "better to be safe than sorry".
– lit. "a little bit too much". "bietjie" (a little bit – "be-key") and "baie" (a lot – "bye-ya")

– a butch, yet friendly and often brave man with a lot of stamina. Someone who will lovingly do something tough no matter if the odds are stacked against him. Derived from the folk song "Jan, Jan, Jan, die bielie van die bosveld". Which describes a man (Jan) who is willing to do any form of hard labour with a smile on his face.
– damn/damnit. Originally from the British English phrase "bloody hell".
– strike, hit, punch; also used often as an expression of surprise/emphasis. It derives from the Dutch word for "lightning", and often occurs in conjunction with
. "Bliksem! Daai weerlig was hard!". (Damn! That lightning-strike was loud!) Used as a curse in Afrikaans: "Jou bliksem!" (You bastard!)
– lit. "damn thing" Used in conjunction with "donnerse".
– literally "blue train", referring to methylated spirits, sometimes used for drinking (filtered through a loaf of white bread). Also refers to the
, a luxury train that travels from Johannesburg to Cape Town via the Trans
rail-line aka "Transkaroo".

– lit. "law-breaker". Refers to any person who has broken a law and got away with it. Derived from the Afrikaans word of the same spelling for "to cuff" (i.e. to arrest, or get arrested). The plural "boewe", refers both to multiple persons in arrest and the handcuffs themselves. Considered outdated as "bliksem" and "skelm" are more commonly used.
– literally "farmer" in Afrikaans. (pronounced boo-(r)). Also the verb "to farm".
– "farmer makes a plan" is an expression used to refer to a creative solution, often low-cost and rather innovative.
– a number of local
that are super effective and cheap. May also be applied to DIY projects.
– a very popular mixed-meat spiced sausage in South Africa. In Afrikaans, literally "farmer's sausage", used as a mainstream word in South African English.
– the South African equivalent of the
, using the
with an onion relish in a hot dog bun
– Anglicism with identical meaning (absolutely nothing), usually succeeding the words "sweet blou/blue" to emphasize the "nothingness" of the topic.
– refers to the geographic region north of Cape Town. See
– lit "to poop". Of unknown origin, it is the Afrikaans equivalent of "poop". Due to the fact that it's the most child-friendly description of
– (diminutive of
, literally meaning "little buck" or "doe") a popular term of endearment, comparable to "sweetheart", "honey", etc. Another meaning for the word
is for a style of beard which is short (often pointy) and stylish and often surrounds just the mouth and chin in a circle (
). Based on the Afrikaans word
(lit. "buck", as well as
– marijuana (literally
– strategy meeting held in a rural setting
, or
– crazy, whacko, mad. Also a term for one who has
. Refers to the time of the
where soldiers spent time in the bush ("bos/bosse") and would return home suffering battle flash-backs (
– a
, to barbecue (from

– grilled meat), used as a mainstream word in South African English. Specifically to grill meat on an open fire. As a noun, it is also the literal area/object used for the grilling of the meat (in that case, the
and stand) as well as the social gathering around it.
– see braai,
– toasted sandwiches that are grilled over an open flame on a braai. Usually served as a side-dish to braaivleis.
– mongrel dog, can also refer to brackish water
– short for "brandewyn" (lit. "brandy")
– panties or ladies underwear. From
, meaning "trousers/briefs". Common usage: "Don't get your broekies in a knot" which means "Calm down".
– ornate ironwork found on Victorian buildings (lit. 'pantie lace'), the tie that you find on board shorts
– a close male friend and a term of affection used by one male to another. All words are variations of the word "broer" in Afrikaans meaning "brother".
(Pronounced 'Boet – tea') specifically means little brother in Afrikaans because of the "ie" diminutive suffix. You could say, "Hey
" or "Thanks a million
for lending me your car". When you refer to another male as
is it because you consider that person to be such a good friend he is like a brother, a family member.
can also be used for strangers but only also if you wish to show a welcoming and friendly attitude towards them or when you want to deescalate tension in a friendly way as in "Chill out
". However you would certainly not walk around calling every man you see,
, because in South Africa the term is not used as loosely as it is in the US for example.
– guests bring their own food and drink (usually pre-prepared, except for the meat) to the

. Traditions surrounding the event usually stipulate that any left-over food and drinks are left behind with the hosts of the party as a parting gift, unless the food was pre-prepared in a personal container.
– lit. "a noisy pony", refers to a
, because a full-size motorcycle is often referred to as an "ysterperd" (iron horse), considering a
is much smaller than a
- lit. "a noise maker" refers to a noisy fly, more specifically to the genus
(which is much larger than its cousin, the common
– duck your head down quickly, as in "Buk when you go in the door; it's really low."
– from the English word meaning (antelope) it refers to money (
), although borrowed from the American term of the same meaning, coincidentally there are two types of bucks featured on the coins of the South African Rand (
on the R1 and
on the R2). Not to be confused with the "Bokke" (
"chop/tjop" – it literally means a piece of meat ("pork chop" or "lamb chop") that you would often cook on a
. If you can call someone a

it means they are being silly or an acting like an idiot, "Don't be a chop". Calling someone a chop often does not mean any harm, it is a light and playful insult and this word is most commonly used in a friendly way between associates. It can also be meant in a teasing way, like "dont be silly".
– lit. means "quickly". Is used when a person has had something done, or wants to have something done in a short amount of time. Derived from the chopping of a knife.
– beautiful girl
– a party/disco where Christian music mainly features; a combination of the words "Christian" and "disco"
– getting high
– refers to a
– most commonly used word for marijuana
– not to be confused with the game of
, it refers to a form of amateur motor-racing where 2 or more vehicles sprint to an impromptu Finish Line on public roads. Often considered to be a part of illegal
, dicing under the legal limit though is usually permitted, though still frowned upon.
– lit. "thick". Can be a derogatory term for being overweight, similar to "dikgat", as well
(or the sensation of being
– grumpy, in a huff (literally: "thick mouth" (pout)
– lit. "fat-arsed". Derogatory term for overweight people, same as "vetgat"
– lit. extremely angry. From "donner", "moer" and "bliksem", all meaning to "hit/ strike (someone)".
– thingamabob, a whatzit or a whatchamacallit. Dutch –
– stupid or slow to understand. "Are you dof?"
– lit. "Thought thought it would plant a feather and then a chicken would come up". Used in retort when someone says they thought something was a good idea and it turned out not to be.
– literally "box". Depending on context, the slang/derogatory version can mean
but most commonly understood as a translation of "arsehole" or "cunt", which in that case would be considered highly offensive.
– idiot (lit. dumbhead), same as German "Dummkopf" or
"domkop"
– emphasis of "stupid idiot"
– to beat up. Same as "bliksem". Derived from "donder" (thunder, related to
– lit. "damn thing". Often used in frustration with another person or thing: "Die donnerse ding wil nie werk nie." ("The damn thing doesn't wanna work").
– alcohol, to drink alcohol, to fail a test. Originally refers to a tot (measure). The diminutive form "doppie" refers to a
– sleep or nap
– lit. "fence sitter". Refers to someone who is uninterested in choosing a side in an argument and therefore remains neutral.
– lit. pull wire, to masturbate
– (Afrikaans) dried boerewors, similar to
– lit. a turd (vulgar); also refers to an arsehole/idiot; a cigarette, with a singly sold cigarette called a 'los drol' ("loose cigarette")
– drunkard
– to embrace or squeeze, hug (noun) "Gee my 'n drukkie," "Give me a hug"
– lit. "score a
, squeeze a turd and insert your finger into your anus". A crude but humorous way to say "go finger-fuck yourself"
– lit. "whoa daddy!"
– ouch!
– Wow! What? Expression of surprise. Of Bantu origin.
– "I say!" Used when making a statement.
– cigarette, can also refer to the act of smoking a cigarette.
– an unfunny (weak) joke (from the Afrikaans word for
), can also refer to weak coffee or tea or weak alcoholic drink. A person that is weak.
– Afrikaans for "fuck", can be used in most ways it is used in English. Fokken = fucking, gefok = fucked. Dutch –
= breeding (animals).
– lit. "fucker".
– lit. "fuckoff" (vulgar)
– lit. "fuck-all". Literally means "absolutely nothing" (vulgar): Ek het fokkol geld ("I've got no money").
– lit. to proceed in a single-minded direction regardless of obstacles. Derived from the phrase: Kyk Noord en Fok voort. (Look North, and go forth).
– lit. "fuck knows". A response to an unanswerable question (vulgar).
– flying poes klap, see poesklap

‘’gabba’’ - the section of anatomy between a man’s anus and scrotum. A combination of ‘gat’ and ‘ballas’: After cycling for five hours my gabba is a bit tender. Could also be used as a derogatory term to refer to a man.
– lit. "hole". Also refers lit. to "arse". Can also be used as a shortened version of the word "gaan" (going to).
– lit. "arse creeping" or
– lit. annoyed enough to the brink of getting angry: Ek is gatvol vir jou kak. (I've had enough of your shit.)
– cigarette
– lit. "a messy person". refers to a person who is behaving, and/or dressing, in a very messy (gemors) manner.

– (pronounced "gate", with the "g" sound in the back of the throat) It literally means "quirks". Usually a negative connotation in relation to a person being either: stubborn, fussy or demanding and sometimes also relating to
. Literal English translation will align it with "-ness" (a.i. hardness, stubbornness). An example is: "hardegat-geit" (lit. hard-arsed and cocky).

– A word to describe someone that acts out in an uncivilzed manner, or refer to lower class person. (other words would be "tappit", :kommen: or when someone is gham it portrays them as being poor and or dirty.). "Ew, that guy is so gham!"
- An expression of unknown origin, describes a person who is wasting time by either laziness or being too slow. Gaap is Afrikaans for
– ugly girl or woman. For example, "What a G!". Also a degrading term for a person of coloured origin.
– bumpkin, redneck (in the
, not to be confused with
, the literal translation of redneck).
– swim, take a dip
– stoned
– throw, chuck or to "tune" (see below) someone
– also chick, cherry: a young woman or girlfriend (used mainly during the 1950s, now dated). Also a famous line by South African comedian Barry Hilton.

– (pronounced with the g-sound in the back of the throat) it refers to a person having an adverse sensory reaction to something that is considered disgusting, creepy or freaky in any way. The closest English equivalent would be "hair-raising". Usually used in the phrase "ek gril myself dood vir...." (i get freaked-out by...).
– also cigarette. derived from "give me a cigarette. Translated – "gee da n gwai"
– lit. "hard-arsed". Describes the stubbornness of a person.
– lit. "Here's comes big shit" Is an expression of revelation towards an often impending and undesired result.

– derived from "How is it going? – contracted to how's it? In South African English context, howzit is more a greeting of "hello" rather than "how are you?", similar to South African black slang's "eta" or "ola"
– lit "
around" by either throwing wild parties, or having casual sex with just about every attractive person you meet, applies to both genders.
– lit. "Whoa there! Stop the
!". Often used to call an immediate halt in whatever is being done, usually in conjunction with a possible undesirable outcome.
– lit. hollow. It also refers to "run very fast" ("Daai man hol so vinning"; "That man runs so fast"). Also refers to anus.
– lit. "anus-ripping". Refers to
laughter.
– lit. "arsehole-floss", refers to a
– informal spelling and pronunciation of "honde" (dogs).
– derogatory term describing people of
ethnic backgrounds, especially those of
-descent (i.e. the majority of Capetonians). The word is derived from the early Dutch term for the Khoi-San people. "Hottentotsgod," or Hottentots' god, is Afrikaans for a
– lit. "time to go home". From "huis+toe" (to+home), "gaan" (go) and "tyd" (time).
– lit. "he'll see his arse" fig. "He'll have his come-uppance"
– lit. "ice-cream car" refers to a purpose-modified vehicle that drives around and sells
. Referred to in the U.S. as an "
" and in the UK as an "ice-cream van". It also is considered a nickname for the
and
, due to both vehicle's immense popularity in that configuration. Even though it is technically a
, it's still referred to as a "karretjie".
– badly damaged, destroyed (rude, often considered profanity due to 'moer' to beat up). often used in conjunction with "moer-in".
– same as above, considered to be less rude.
– informal combined spelling of the phrases "in die" (in the) and "op die" (on the).
– lit. "you are thrilled". Used to describe levels of excitement, similar to "tickled pink".
– commonly pronounced as "iepie-corners", refers to

. Unlike the actual disorder, it is often used to comically exaggerate a person's reaction to any kind of symptoms that are generally considered harmless regardless of the discomfort caused by them. Like when someone drinks cough-syrup after coughing just twice.
– yeah (literally "yes" in Afrikaans)
– lit. "Jacob upright". Refers to an erect
– lit. "Jackal weds Wolf's wife". Refers to the weather phenomena known as a "
". Can be used to describe an unlikely situation. Also refers to a song of the same name by Afrikaans singer
– Meaning "horny". For example, "Jinne meisie, jy maak my nou sommer lekker jags."
– literally "yes-no", an expression of positive confirmation.
Example :
("It's hot today") :
("Indeed")
– lit. "Jan Every man". Local variant of the American term "
- Bypass, hack, slacking, short-term fix. I'll jippo the alarm to not make a sound while we work on it. While the team was working hard all night, Byron was jippoing.
- Diarrhoea
– expression of surprise, can be positive or negative. Often used when you get a fright, but equally often during particularly exciting parts of a rugby game.
– a shortened version of "jislaaik".
– another variation of "jislaaik".
– informal for "yes".
– an exclamation e.g., "Jo, that was rude," "Jo, you gave me a fright!" Pronounced as in "yolk".
– to have fun, to party, can also refer to a disco or party, to commit adultery or even dating or courting
– lit. "your mom's pussy" (vulgar).

– the shortened version of "Juffrou". "Juffrou" is a shortened version of the formal title given to address a young unmarried woman "Mejuffrou" (Miss). It is also the formal title given to address a female teacher of any age or marital status, whereby "Juffie" would be considered informal.
– lit. "naked arse". Derived from the word "kaal" (naked), it's simply a more humorous description. Similar to the English term "
– A strong south-eastern wind in the
-area. Called the "doctor" due to the belief that it clears the
air of its pollution.
– lit. "
turn", refers to a folk song (of the same name) that describes a flightpath around the Cape Peninsula literally as the
flies (known as a Witborskraai in Afrikaans), can now be applied to actual
around the peninsula. Singer
released a single based on the folk song, with the same name. It also jokingly refers to a car that turns far to wide (i.e. like crossing into the oncoming lane).
– refers to a
, though it can also refer to a small non-
serving grocery shop or
– Offensive pejorative referring to a black African. Derived from the Arabic word
meaning a non-Muslim, which included black Africans along the Swahili coast.
– a phrase referring to the consumption of
. Often used by black South Africans at shebeens.

– Literal translation: shit, crap, rubbish, nonsense (vulgar), of very wide usage. Also used as a way of further expressing one's feeling in language, for example, instead of "that girl is pretty" one can say emphatically "that girl is kak pretty!"

– lit "shit and pay". Used when frustrated about spending all your hard-earned money on family, or friends, and having none left for yourself. Closest English equivalent is "Cough it up and pay up", but it doesn't have anywhere near the same power.
– lit. "shithouse". Refers to both a toilet and the bathroom it is located in, as well as "a lot of".
– lit. "shithouse/shitload". Refers to a troublesome situation as well as an exaggerated amount of money.
- lit "(I can't) died from pushing a

". The phrase "ek kan nie" (shortened to kannie = cannot/can't) is personified as a lazy man. The phrase is used as a form of motivation and discipline, implying that if you can do a physical task as easy as pushing a wheelbarrow, then you are more than capable enough to do any kind of hard work.
– lit. "kat's spit". Refers to a very small amount of something, similar to "bietjie" (a little bit)
– derogatory term for an English person. From the colour worn by British troops, as well as the traditional clothes worn by
(Afrikaans speaking white farmers).
– police (original Afrikaans meaning: guys, chaps). "The kêrels are coming, watch out!" (dated). More commonly referring to boyfriend or literal translation: Guy or young man. Dutch –
– lit. "curry and rice", is a popular South African variant of a
usually served with rice and
– (adjective) wicked, cool, neat, great, wonderful. The word derives from the Arabic word
, meaning pleasure or marijuana. This may also be related to the Afrikaans word for poison:
. Coastal pot-smokers used the term to refer to Durban Poison: "Gifs" [locally-grown marijuana]. The word evolved into
, an adjective or exclamation meaning "cool", among English-speaking people on the east coast.
– pronounced "key-ki"; refers to a photograph
– (pronounced "klaas faacky") refers to the mythical creature known as the
, can also ironically refer to people who had just now woken up late.
– lit. "a sound", Can also mean unpleasant smell. Used in conjunction with "klank". Pronounced as in "clunk"

– to smack. (from Afrikaans). "He got klapped in the bar". Like a "bitch-slap", but much worse. Another variation on this is the "kopklap" (getting slapped hard over the head), typically done by a parent of authority figure as a form of discipline.
– lit. a
– Klipdrift, a brandy preferred by mostly Afrikaans men, usually leading to chinas getting bliksemed

– lit. "stone-stroke". Used to jokingly refer to a person who can't swim even if their life depended on it and thus sinks like a stone in water, this is mostly a joking self-reference by pessimistic swimmers.
– lit. "bells". The plural of the word "klok" (derived from "clock"). It also refers to a man's
– an anglicism of "goodbye".

– lit. "cake". Can be used to refer to a response to a sticky situation: "O Koek" (Oh Shit); clumped hair that is messy: Jou hare is gekoek (Your hair is very messy and difficult to brush); Can also refer to a

– A sweet pastry that's been fried and dipped in a honey syrup, and shaped in the form of a French-braid. It doesn't have anything to do with a sibling – "sister" is "suster" in Afrikaans. The "sis" refers to the sound it makes when fried in oil. Alternative spelling is koesister. It also can refer to lesbians, or female genitalia: "I can like to be teasing my koeksister while I are wearing a rokkie"
– a camp male waiter or male flight attendant. See "moffie".
– lit. "either-or". An expression, of French origin, that states the user isn't sure about an answer and doesn't care either. Similar to the expression "tamato-tomato".
– same as "cunt" in English (profanity)
– lit. "cup". Also refers to a relatively small
, (with "koppie" being the diminutive form of "kop") in reference to it appearing like a small head (kop) poking out of the ground.
– lit. "head noise". someone who talks endlessly
– lit. "short arse". Cutesy nickname given to shorter-than average people, can be considered offensive unlike its antonym "langeraad".
– (from "kots") lit. "to vomit" (vulgar)
– old person
– lit. "crow's nest". While the original English meaning stays intact, it can also refer to a big mess. Whether it be messy hair, a messy bedroom or a loud and messy gathering, like a party.
– literally means "crayfish" but it refers to a promiscuous woman with the intent to attract men.

– lit. "get a cramp". A definitive expression of strong disagreement, usually used to end an argument regardless if the issue was resolved. Can also be used to refer to exaggerated negative feelings towards a stubborn person: Ek wens hy kry 'n kramp! (I wish he gets a cramp!). Used in conjunction with "gaan kak!".
– cool, excellent (Afrikaans: "angry". Compare the US slang word
– visitor from northern provinces, especially Gauteng, to Cape Town; from "kyk daar!" – "just look at that!". See also "soppiekoppie".
- To continue without any clear plan in mind. To play it by ear. Directly translates to "Look North and fuck onward."

– lit. "looking through closed eyes". Contrary to "kyk aan die binnekant van jou ooglede" (which means to take a nap, or go to sleep), it refers to a person who is wide awake, yet cannot spot the item they're looking for that's right under their nose. Used in conjunction with "As dit 'n slang was, dan sou hy jou gepik het"

– lit. "late lamb", refers to the youngest child in a family, specifically if there is a significant age-gap between the child and their older sibling (or more specifically when there is 3 or more siblings; the 2nd youngest sibling). It should also be considered that the parents' are at an advanced age at that point. Laatlammetjies refer to a set of youngest siblings that are close in age to each other, but with a significant age gap between their older siblings. For example:
(4yrs old) and
(1yr old), from the
series
, are 12 and 16 years younger (respectively) than their older middle-brother

"Ek klap 'n ding wat laf raak!" (Jokingly "clap"). (Soft way of saying you've lost it or you're a clown!)

– a younger person, esp. a younger male such as a younger brother or son

", it describes a goodlooking tall blonde-haired, and usually blue-eyed, man.
– (n) boss, used in a different tone. (adj.) fancy

– 1. an act that is undesirable to commit, a burden. 2. To tell someone or suggest to stop doing an act. (origin: something that is slowing you or an object down; for example, "'n Las in die pad.", meaning "An object as in a stone in the road."). 3. To physically join two separate objects together: (Las die punte van die twee toue aanmekaar; Tie the two ends of the ropes together.)
– lit. "lion walk". Popularized by singer-comedian
in the song of the same name, it refers to a sex dance (but slightly more humorous than vulgar). The song mainly describes a man getting down on

– (lit. tasty) It means pleasing, tasty, nice, good, great, delicious.
is used for just about anything you find nice. "How was the party?
", "I met a
chick last night", "local is

bro". Unlike its English counterpart "nice", use of the word "lekker" is actually promoted instead of frowned upon despite being very commonly used. It is speculated that "lekker" will never become
– lit. "truck". Derived from the English word "

" with an identical meaning, the term gained popularity after the British colonized South Africa. Though "trok" (the proper Afrikaans translation for "truck") is still in use, it has been heavily replaced with the slang term "lorrie". Is sometimes used to jokingly compare cars that are just as difficult to drive as an actual truck.
– lit. "loose, loose child." A really slutty girl, usually wears revealing clothes and is easy to get with (for example: "Sarah is 'n fokken loskind!")
– air head, literally a "lost head" refers to someone whose head is in the clouds, clumsy, forgetful.
– a person who sleeps around a lot (i.e. "whore/manwhore", but not as derogatory)
– to have a craving for. "I lus for a cigarette". (Also see "smaak".)
– collective references to both parents which can be either centered around the mother (ma) or father (pa). Based on the word
(them).

– lit. "make like Rokoff and fuckoff!" Of unknown origin, is a crude way of telling someone to go away. Is similar to the English sayings like: Make like
" and "Make like eggs, and scramble".

– friend (
), also partner (wife, girlfriend)

– mother

or a
made from recycled clay/mortar.

has a strong milk flavour and is best served with a dash of cinnamon sprinkled on top.

being on offer.

) / maize (
), staple diet. The base ingredient of

– is a strong blend of ground-coffee usually served with minimal milk in a tin-based mug.
– comically describes a person's temperament for their tolerance of bullshit. Derived from the red
and used as a metaphor as illustrated by
when he gets mad. Used in conjunction with "bloediglik vererg".
– a very strong word for big, for example: "that's a moerse house"
– a point in time when a person's patience has worn so thin, he could snap violently at any moment. Derived from a
(moer) that strips its threads when excessive force is applied.

– retard ("Liesl, you are such a mompie!")
– "well done, man", used as an expression of appreciation in another person's achievement.
– lit. "money". Is the English slang term for money as well as the name of the actual mobile-currency used in the now defunct
– boring, sterile, unexciting ("This is more morne than watching Saracens play!")

– Afrikaans, implies that what has been said is well known or self-evident (a formal part of grammar, the closest English equivalent would be "duh!"). "Ek drink mos tee." ("I drink tea, duh!"). Used at the end of a sentence, as in "...Jy weet mos." ("...Obviously, as you know.")
– lit. "sparrow-fart" based on the definition of
(oversleeping in the morning), it refers to a very early "waking up time" in the morning, often more specifically before 6:00AM (before
wake up, but after the
crow)
– bug, especially a little flying gnat
– cigarette
"mung" – the term mung means to lose a life playing video games and it also represents Pallsmoor jail, you gonna go to the"mung" when you stolen something and you get caught by police.

– lit. "mix it language". Refers to the text-based grammar usage that was popularized by the now-defunct Mxit, a free instant messaging service. For example: Eng: How R U? Afrikaans: Hoe ganit? (Hoe gaan dit?); Eng: I'm gr8 (I'm great).
(Afrikaans) – copulate; but strictly speaking "sew", from the action of a sewing machine needle.

– do you know what I mean/agree?, oh really?, is it not so? or British English "innit?". Similar to the French "n'est-ce pas" and the Portuguese "né?", meaning "Isn't it?", e.g. "Jy hou van tee, nè?" ("You like tea, not so?") (informal). The South African English equivalent is "hey", for example "Eish, its cold hey?".
– lit. "to hit", less vulgar than "moer", "donner" and "bliksem"

– "nineteen-voetsek" (Commonly pronounced "neëntien"; "nie'an teen"), refers to a date in the early 20th century, with "voetsek" (go far away) referring to a very early date. Translation: a very long time ago, often used when the specific date isn't known.
– of all things. Term expressing a measure of surprise.
– lit. "never." No way, unbelievable!
– lit. "Immediately/now". Also means "narrow".
– lit. "just now". Refers to an event that happened within a few minutes ago.
– contrary to the original meaning of the English word "now", it means "in due time", and therefore can mean anything from "in the next five minutes" to "in the next five years".

– lit. "just now." Can refer to an event that happened a while ago, maybe within 12hrs ("I saw him just now"). Or some time in the future ("I'm coming just now"), which could mean anything from 5 minutes to 5 years, or never.

– lit. "just just". Refers to something/someone that has either impeccable timing and/or is just shy from, and just far enough to, winning any competitive event. English equivalents are: "Just in the nick of time", "just shy of winning", "almost". For example: Ek het my eksamen vraestel net-net deur gekom (I just barely passed my exam).
– lit. "Now we're gonna Braai!". Pokes fun at the
of the braaier, who intends to start immediately, but doesn't start till much much later.
– lit. "Oh Gosh!". A catchphrase uttered by the beloved witch

when calling out her magic horse, Griet, whom she's able to conjure-up with the phrase, though she never remembers his name and as a result she only ever summons him by accident whenever she's in panic. The popularity of the catchphrase ensured that it gained use via the general public and therefore is used by a person whenever their in a state of panic.
– ("g" sound pronounced in the back of the throat) Derived from "O Gonna" ("Oh Shit", but not vulgar), the singer
's name was added to the phrase by

for comedic rhyming effect, it has since become one of his signature catchphrases along with: "O gatta patata" and "Oh Schucks" (both mean "Oh Shit", and the latter was inspired by Leon's own last name).
– an older man of authority, commonly in reference to an older Afrikaans man (Afrikaans for "uncle")
(diminutive
plural =
) man, guy, bloke (also
) (literally "old")
– lit. "old head." Refers usually to an elderly man and a father.
– lit. "old little ball(s)." Old man, dad; as in: "shaft me, ouballie" "My ouballie (father, dad) will be home soon".
– also called "mieliepap", is a traditional maize ("mielie") porridge similar to
; can also mean "deflated". Pap (porridge) is primarily known in three stages; all three are variant to the water-to-maize ratio:
(lit. "stiff-pap"; 3/4 water-to-maize),
(pap with a crumbly texture; 1/4 water-to-maize) and

(pap with a runny texture; 4/3 water-to-maize). Unlike most international porridges, pap (specifically the aforementioned phutupap and stywepap variations) is commonly served at both breakfast and dinner times in the Northern half of the country.
– lit. "pap-spoon"; a wooden spoon used in the making of pap, but can also be used to give a hiding
– lit. "flat/uninflated hole." Tired or weak.

– lit. "to pack". Also means "to give a hiding", as the shortened version of pakslae, a "parcel of hidings"

". A favourite side-dish for Afrikaners, the name "patat" ("pah-tut") can also become a pet-name or
– lit. "to stick". Can also refer to starting an informal settlement like a

. Can refer to an idiot, but is less derogatory and often used to lightly joke with the person in question.

". When someone is accusing another person of
them: Jy probeer my se dat perdedrolle is fye! (You're trying to tell me that horseshit is figs!)
– lit. "farm". Also, when someone falls down:
. As a verb, it translates to "placed down" or "put down"

". Refers to anything that is considered too expensive regardless of its actual worth, considering that a farm is one of the most expensive pieces of property one could privately own.

. Its closest English counterpart would be "it's like talking to a brick wall".
– lit. "to smell a fart". Refers to a person who is sleeping in late, though it specifically points to the person wasting time because of it.

– lit. "vagina hit." A very hard slap. similar to "klap" (to smack/slap), but far more painful: Ek gaan jou so 'n harde poesklap gee, jou tanne gaan vibreer vir maande lank. (I'm gonna smack you so hard, that your teeth will vibrate for months). Poesklap therefore is far more life-threatening than a "bitch-slap".

). It is a
towards young beautiful women, and can also extend to much younger girls usually via a grandfather-figure. The closest English equivalent would be "poppet".

– lit. "animal paws". Is an informal reference to a person's feet ("voete" in Afrikaans) directly relating the condition and size of the feet to that of an animal's paws. Also derogatory term for police officers (plural).

– (pronounced "poi-key") lit. the diminutive form of the English/Afrikaans word "pot", referring to the cooking utensil, but more specifically a small-to-large sized cast iron pot that is traditionally used to make
– lit. "small pot food". Is a meat and vegetable dish that is specially cooked in a
. It is traditionally slow-cooked over an open fire for a couple of hours before being served during a

(social gathering). Though it is similar to a stew, the main differences are: a stew has much water/sauce, while a potjiekos has very little water/sauce; and you stir a stew, you don't stir potjiekos as it is intended to not have the individual ingredients' flavor mixing. Potjiekos is traditionally served with phutupap or samp. Though it is considered a meal on its own, it can also be served as a
to
and
) (as both would take up a considerable amount of space on the plate).

in theatre and a

, the English pronunciation (in its original meaning) is also regularly used by Afrikaners, though it is separated from the Afrikaans pronunciation's meaning. For example: Ek moet die video pause (Eng pro.) omdat ons nou op pause (Afr pro.) gaan. (I have to pause the video because we're going on recess now.)

– lit. "directionless". Refers to any person who becomes easily disorientated when no visual references are helping their navigation, i.e. they feel lost very easily. It can also be used to humorously describe a person's poor

can get lost in his own house."

– lit. "Reed bed", i.e. "bunk bed", considered out-dated as references to bunk beds in general fell out of use in favour of the English term. Original Afrikaans translation for "bunk-bed" is "stapelbed". Riet ("Reed") refers to the bunk bed frame's flimsy appearance while "kooi" is the slang term for a bed (specifically a single-bed), derived from the Capetonian dialect. "Kooi" is still in use in the Southern regions.
– ("roll") A fight or brawl.
– to fight.

– ("red neck") Afrikaner derogatory term for English person or English-speaking South African. Derived in the 19th century due to native British not being used to the hot African sun and getting sunburnt, especially on the neck. Alternative explanation, reference to the fact that British officers during the two Boer Wars had red collars.

that wore

about the titular

– to move or pull. (The word has become international with the meaning of "making a pioneering journey"; the slang usage more closely resembles the standard Afrikaans meaning.)

, as it can be used to tow (pull) trailers and/or cars.
– lit. "aunt/mother". Derived from the Dutch word

(aunt), it refers to any older female authority figure. The female counterpart of "oom" (uncle). Though the original English meaning stays intact, the term has come to indicate a sign of tremendous respect towards a much older woman. Rules in using the term correctly are: The woman must be at least 10 years older than oneself, otherwise they might consider it offensive towards their age if they are young; unless she is one's real-life aunt, referring to a woman as "tannie" is purely permission-based, i.e. if she doesn't accept the term (and she'll tell you), then you should refrain from using it when addressing her.
– taken from the word "tiekieboks/ticky box", is the popular name of the now outdated streetside

. Though ticky boxes are still in use, they have been largely replaced by cellphones. The ticky box takes its name from the limited time-period per call, based on the ticking of a timer. Also the name given to the old 2 and a half cent piece and later the 5 cent piece.

, with "tok-tok" being the
of the sound the bird makes while pecking. Also refers to the woodpecker-style birds used in some
– a children's game where you knock on someones door and run away before they answer.

(based on the German/Afrikaans pronunciation – "folks-vach-en"). It essentially translates to "little Volkswagen". Also known as a "Volla".
– Afrikaans, meaning an animal dying. Possibly from Dutch
to dislocate? Is considered extremely rude when used to refer to a person that has died, as the person would be likened to a mere animal.
– lit. "the quicker the fruit
, the quicker it will
". Refers to anything that is being rushed.
– bad, rotten, putrid, sometimes drunk
– someone who swears a lot or is swearing a lot at the moment, as well as someone with bad breath.
– to make out or courting (equivalent to American "necking", British "snogging" or Australian "pashing")
– shifting spanner
– lit. "dirty mouth", refers someone who swears a lot or is swearing a lot at the moment.
– lit. "dirty owl", an unsavoury character, a person of ill repute, guilt of transgressions
– Afrikaans for "wave hello/goodbye". Slang for "to go". Durbanites like to say "Hey, let's waai pozzy." = "Let's go home." Also refers to the blowing of wind.
– Afrikaans slang to describe a good day or thing, using Weber. Originated from a High School teachers attitude and the students adopted it.

– lit. "Where did you fall off the bus?". Is a question usually asked when the person you are talking to, wasn't paying attention to the topic changing when they joined the discussion, and as a result they usually interrupt the discussion with an off-topic question.
– lit. "what also all." Whatever.
– despite its original Dutch meaning "worry", it can also be used to verbally "wake-up" a drowsy person.
– lit. "wind hole." A loquatious over-talkative, perhaps bragging person.
– wild, untidy, unkempt or irreverent. A general term pertaining to either a person, behaviour or situation. Also could mean angry, in a rage, or sexually aroused.
– lit. "become awake, the day is getting ever-weaker." A wake-up call in military fashion, usually is accompanied with loud banging on the door.

– multiple meanings – to insult (see tune) or to say e.g. "Yoh, John wys me after I told him to shut up!". Also refers to "wysheid" (wisdom/wise) in a sarcastic tone: "O jy dink jy's wys né! (You think you're smart huh, do you!)
– an expression of surprise e.g., "Yoh, that was rude" "Yoh, you gave me a fright!", (Police-chief talking about the poor physique of his policemen): "They should look at our men and say "yoh!".
– "iron horse", describes a motorcycle, specifically a
-style "full-size" motorcycle. Is derived from the fact that a motorcycle, with all its uses, is the modern day equivalent of a horse-and-rider.
– lit. "iron piglets". Also known by their English/Australian name "
", these are small cubes of sponge cakes dipped in chocolate syrup and covered in desiccated coconut. It takes its Afrikaans name from the
(Afrikaans for
) due to its resemblance to the animal.
– while the original English usage remains intact, though the term "to shock" is preferred, it also refers to one's obscene usage of
, while a "double-zap" would be where both middle fingers are extended at the same time.
– from the Ford Zephyr car, cheap to tune up; cool, rough guy; common person; kitsch, trashy
– a homemade cigarette rolled with old newspaper or Rizla pape, possibly
-filled, equivalent to American "doobie"
– is usually used when exclaiming agreement like you would when saying "sweet!", "nice!", "lekker!", and "got it!".
– a wonderful smelling range of medicinal plants.
(has become a mainstream word in South African English) (from Khoe
for
plant)
– exclamation of pain, as in
(from Khoekhoe exclamation of pain or surprise)
– bug (from Khoe
, creeping things, here the
is pronounced like
in Scottish
– garment made of animal skin (from Khoe meaning skin blanket)
– a

, or cane, usually made of wood. Primarily used by the elderly as general usage of a cane fell out of fashion among younger generations, though people still have a habit of when carrying a stick to use it as a walking stick, even though they don't necessarily need it.
the act of carrying a child on your back. Is a tradition of tribal African women to carry their young hands-free on their backs by literally binding them in a
-like garment, emulating the pouch of a
– not on your nellie; nice try. Sometimes a strong refusal/disagreement, No!
– (pronounced: chai-leh) "time to go home"
– “how is it going?”
– used to describe a feeling of loss or disappointment (It is what it is or it's over in other words) e.g. "That test was chaai!" or "i lost my money it's chaai because I won't get it back "
– "meddie" could mean girl or girlfriend e.g. "is that your cherry "
– “what’s up?” [[from Sotho and Tswana people)
– a friend (similar to English "chum")
– meaning "to see: (the c is pronounced as a dental click). It can be used meaning both "to see" or "to understand" as in "Did you cav that ?" or as in "Do you cav what I am saying?"
– small tip truck on rails used in mines (from Nguni
, Scotch cart)
– lit. "wall" (Xhosa). Small erosion channel, akin to arroyo in Mexico.
– an interjection expressing resignation
– expert (from
"umfundisi" meaning teacher or preacher) – used in mainstream South African English
– to put (pronounced as fuh-kuh) from the common Nguni word meaning the same thing, faka
– grandmother, elderly woman (from Mbo-Nguni,
– expression of disbelief, surprise. Pronounced like English "how!". From the Zulu "hawu".
– has no direct English translation. It's used as an exaggerated response to something and can be apply to any situation (from Zulu, 'definitely not').
– meeting of the community (from Nguni, 'a matter for discussion'); has become a mainstream word in South African English in the sense of consultative conference.
– traditional herbalist and healer (compare with
– injection, to inject (from Zulu)
– a popular cheer at soccer matches, "he scores!" (literally: "it thunders", in
– meaning something is nice or tasty (the
is a nasalised dental click)
– water, kasi word for water,also the name of a water purification company from standerton Sakhile
– medicine (from Nguni
) – typically traditional African
– South Africa (
in Xhosa means "south"), specifically refers to the South Africa.
– (pronounced "Ngc-ah", dental click) an expression of appreciation or admiration, similar to "nice"
– Term used to refer to a maid, usually a black female; also used by black females to call/refer to each other (from Sesotho and Setswana for 'sister)
– traditional healer or diviner
(also spelt
(from Nguni,
, 'to roll up')
- of Xhosa origin, lit means to "burn meat". Is the Zulu equivalent to the
– an informal trading-post/convenience store found in townships and remote areas (also a term referring to something cheap and nasty – i.e. of poor quality)
– a dwarf-like water sprite, taken from
– (more commonly spelt toi-toi) protest-dancing; used in mainstream South African English
– gangster, layabout, no gooder
– compassion or kindness, humanity, connectedness
– a traditional horn made from the hollowed-out horns of a

bull. It produces a monotonous tone and is often used as a summonings. A modernized version is made from plastic and more closely resembles a straight trumpet. The modern version is commonly used by the audience at
games, though usage of it has been highly frowned upon and in some cases banned because of noise-regulations, due to its incredibly loud blaring monotonous tone.
- A friend of yours
– lit. "yes" (Mbo-Nguni)
– Literally "you" (Mbo-Nguni). Commonly used in a sentence "Hayi
– a girl, from Arabic بِنْت. Usually seen as derogatory.
– the main unit of currency: in South Africa
, and from the American use of the word for the dollar.
– friend, mate (from
= "mate").
– to eat
– a state of affairs that surpasses cool
– name for an English person originating from England
short for shebeen.
– derogatory term for
people in South Africa. Derived from "Gham" or "Ham" referring to Ham in the Old Testament. It is a reference to the children of Noah's son Ham who were illegitimate and cursed into slavery by God.
– "you all" appears across all
of
Its lexical similarity to the
of the United States is attributed to coincidence.
(plural

: "a sinner"): approximately equivalent to "trashy white talk". The word refers particularly to poor, white, Afrikaans-speaking communities with endemic social problems. Sometimes used as an ethnic slur against Afrikaners in general. From
phrase
– a
– (uncouth ignoramus) is not afraid of sin. The bor-Boer
gives a case for
: if not afraid of sin must be therefore a sinner.
: a low-class, unmannered and unsophisticated person regardless of wealth, usually Jewish. The etymology is unclear.
(Theories: (a) Yiddish corruption of
(b) derives from an acronym for "Polish and Russian Union", supposedly a Jewish club founded in Kimberley in the 1870s, according to Bradford's
) The more assimilated and established Jews from Germany and England looked down on this group, and their descendants remain stigmatised.
: Yiddish / German for "black" – a black person
: as in other Jewish communities, this means "non-Jewish girl". Traditionally "slave-girl", from the Yiddish version of the Hebrew word for "dirty, unclean, loathsome"
In South Africa, however, it has the additional meaning of a "female domestic worker".
(historical)
